title: Petition: Do not remove LGBT content from the Relationships Education curriculum

last_post.content:
I am going to keep posting about this until we get to 100,000 signatures.

So,you have seen posts like this before and you are getting bored of seeing it. However, the rate of increase in the number of votes is decreasing. I know we can do this, so please help me out.

As I write there are 87,960 signatures. The linear trend line of signatures from Tuesday 31 January gives an equation of
y = 1076.9x + 82277.
That means the date for hitting 100,000 votes has drifted out three days to Wednesday 15 February. I know we can do better than this. The last we thing we want is the petition to remove LGBT content from the curriculum to be debated and our opinion not to be heard.

Please sign if you are in the UK and please boost if you are not.

May I take this opportunity to thank each and everyone of the 900 people that have boosted this post so far. ❤️ ❤️

Petition: Do not remove LGBT content from the Relationships Education curriculum

https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/631529

#TransRightsAreHumanrRghts #Trans

"Google Search was based on principles set out in founder Larry Page and Sergey Brin's landmark 1998 paper, "Anatomy of a Large-Scale Hypertextual Web Search Engine," in which they wrote, "Advertising funded search engines will be inherently biased towards the advertisers and away from the needs of consumers." title: Unable to burn digital books, Orange Unified School District bans the whole virtual library | Boing Boing

last_post.content:
One thing I'll say for the wave of Republican book-banning that's going on right now -- it's certainly making books seem powerful and *significant*

Book-banning is of course a terrible way to have the public re-realize the catalytic effect a good book can have on its readers

Nonetheless, here we are: https://boingboing.net/2023/01/31/unable-to-burn-digital-books-orange-unified-school-district-bans-the-whole-virtual-library.html

title: Stop Talking to Each Other and Start Buying Things: Three Decades of Survival in the Desert of Social Media

last_post.content:
“Stop benefitting from the internet, it’s not for you to enjoy, it’s for us to use to extract money from you.

Stop finding beauty and connection in the world, loneliness is more profitable and easier to control.”

Right on, about Big Tech.
By @catvalente in Dec

https://catvalente.substack.com/p/stop-talking-to-each-other-and-start

title: sciencedirect.com/science/arti...

last_post.content:
There's an interesting new paper in the journal Ecological Economics. The title is:

"Assessing US consumers' carbon footprints reveals outsized impact of top 1%"
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0921800922003597

This is from the abstract --

Unsustainable environmental degradation and extreme economic inequality are two of humanity's most pressing challenges. They are intimately linked. Climate-altering greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions are disproportionately driven by consumption among wealthy and socially privileged groups, yet poorer and socially marginalized peoples face disproportionate climate harms.
________________________

What really grabbed me, however, was the chart below, created by Andrew Fanning using data contained in the paper. It clearly illustrates the massive scale of carbon inequality in our modern society.

#Inequality #GreenhouseGases #Emissions #ClimateCrisis #ClimateJustice

title: arXiv announces new policy on ChatGPT and similar tools – arXiv.org blog

last_post.content:
ArXiv issues new policy on large language models as authors: https://blog.arxiv.org/2023/01/31/arxiv-announces-new-policy-on-chatgpt-and-similar-tools/

TL;DR: no, language models cannot take responsibility for the content of a paper and therefore cannot be listed as an author

title: Getty Images v. Stability AI - Complaint

last_post.content: BREAKING: Getty Images just filed a copyright and trademark infringement lawsuit against Stability AI in Delaware District Court. Getty alleges that Stability copied more than 12 million Getty photos to train Stable Diffusion. Full complaint here: https://copyrightlately.com/pdfviewer/getty-images-v-stability-ai-complaint/

title: Sam Bankman-Fried is not a child

last_post.content:
Only reading headlines and news stories, you would be forgiven if up until now you had thought SBF was a teenager still driving around on a learner’s permit, who picked up crypto trading to avoid high school summer jobs that might force him to go outside.

https://newsletter.mollywhite.net/p/sam-bankman-fried-is-not-a-child

title: UnitedHealthcare tried to deny coverage to a chronically ill patient. He fought back, exposing the insurer’s inner workings.

last_post.content: This article from @ProPublica is a long read, but completely worth it. It pulls back the curtain of what happens behind the scenes at health insurance companies. It is frightening, frustrating, and incredibly accurate. https://www.propublica.org/article/unitedhealth-healthcare-insurance-denial-ulcerative-colitis

title: From the Community | Stanford needs an official Mastodon server

last_post.content:
Stanford student @tguarna is calling for Stanford University to host its own Mastodon server.

The reason is simple: Twitter is no longer reliable as communications infrastructure.

Academics and researchers need reliable communications infrastructure.

And it's time for universities like Stanford to ensure the reliability of their communications!

https://stanforddaily.com/2023/02/02/from-the-community-stanford-needs-an-official-mastodon-server/

title: The Cement Mixer Space Capsule of Winganon

last_post.content:
A cement truck crashed near Winganon, Oklahoma in the 1950s and the mixer was too heavy to move. It’s still there; locals have painted it to look like an abandoned NASA
capsule.

title: Open Review of the Second Half of “After Disruption: A Future for Cultural Memory”

last_post.content:
Starting on revisions to respond to peer reviews of my forthcoming book, After Disruption: A Future for Cultural Memory. For background on the book, you can read the full drafts of it here http://www.trevorowens.org/2022/07/open-review-of-the-second-half-of-after-disruption-a-future-for-cultural-memory/ and here http://www.trevorowens.org/2022/01/open-review-of-the-first-half-of-after-disruption-a-future-for-cultural-memory/

I am planning to add some additional targeted positive examples of cultural memory work/projects/initiatives that model centering an ethic of care, a maintenance mindset, and a focus on repair.

title: Academia’s culture of overwork almost broke me, so I’m working to undo it

last_post.content:
"But I now realize that, by hiding behind passion, I was excusing my contribution to a toxic burnout culture in research. And for me and many others like me — female, immigrant, non-native English speakers — the pressures are even greater. It’s time to speak out."

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00241-8

#academia #AcademicChatter

title: Is cycling safe? In many cases, the answer is no.

last_post.content:
Very big implications to finding (2 studies, in London & Paris) that woman cyclists get killed more than men because they wait for signal to start across intersection.
This is surely true for pedestrians too, since geometry is the same.
Implies that using marked crosswalk & obeying signal is often more dangerous than violating law. 1/2
https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2023/01/is-cycling-safe-in-many-cases-the-answer-is-no/
https://www.lemonde.fr/les-decodeurs/article/2023/02/04/que-peut-on-dire-de-la-hausse-inquietante-des-morts-de-cyclistes_6160557_4355770.html
